Posted: July 3, 2013
												This is the kind of space-combat game I've wanted for a long time. Set to 2d controls, you must pilot one of the ships your mothership can store and explore the galaxy in a quest to progress to the middle. A wide array of weapons and procedurally generated galaxies make this one excellent example of a space game.

Posted: January 16, 2012
												This is a really fun genre-bending game. It mixes action, exploration, strategy and rpg elements together into something really unique and quite addictive. Explore a randomly generated galaxy while building and customizing your fleet of ships. Collect blueprints to widen your available equipment and pour research into tech trees to make your fleet more effective. The game can get a little repetitive, friendly AI seems to suck often, and the difficulty can seem like a roller coaster sometimes. That being said I still enjoyed this game a ton and recommend it if you like top-down shooters, action rpgs or space ships.

Posted: September 15, 2014
												A little mundane at first; there's a lot of information to be conveyed (not information overload, but it pays to read the tutorial screens). The progression of weapons, armor, shields, ship types, and much more keep you playing till the end. Then, in my case starting over on a harder difficulty. There's a lot to like here; the one thing that's a little hard to get used to is the controls are relative to your ship, and not to the screen. I suspect it would have been too easy if they were relative to the screen, but finding that perfect balance of cargo hold, crew capacity and firepower at any given time is great fun.

At time of writing, this is on sale for 2.50.Buy this game.

We'll shoot!"And also Bounty Hunters! "All your rez belongs to us!"Get it now! Before there's no resource left and the zombies have eaten you alive! ;)

Posted: January 10, 2014
												As of the writing of this review I have just under 300 hr.s played on this game.It doesn't look like it when you first start; but this is an epic journey.Yes, after you reach the top tier of tech...it's a bit easy.  But guess what?  You're playing it like a pansy then!  Turn up the difficulty!  Die so much you cry.In my opinion, infinite replayability.  This game is a perfect top-down shmup with a decent story and RPG elements such as upgrading your technology and choosing/fitting the perfect fleet to get blown up.Enjoy your certain doom!

Posted: January 20, 2014
												Over all, this is one of my favorite games on steam. I was very surprised to see how much fun it all would be and I totally recommend giving it a try and if it goes on sell, you likely can't go wrong picking up a copy.S.P.A.Z. reminds me a whole lot of one of my fav games of all time, EscapeVelocity. I remember playing EV on our Mac years and years ago. It left such a good impression that I watched the companies website like a hawk for almost a decade for signs of windows development, and promptly bought a copy.There isn't any market trading in SPAZ, it's all about the combat and ship upgrades. And it's incredibly satisfying to finally unlock that next high capacity ship and beef up your little squadron and go tearing through hostile territories. I was delaying what I thought would complete the game, and then I finally went forward with the quest and realized that a whole new world of gameplay opens up toward the end of the game. It feels a little more tedious than the rest of the game, but still something I will go back and play quite often it was so much fun. The visuals are great, simple sprites unleashing very pretty particles of destruction all in front of really beautiful galactical backdrops. The music is more ambient and moody than pulse pumping "ReallyBigSky" type stuff but it fits the situation very well.There were a few mechanics that are sticking points because of how vaguely they're explained (if at all) and I played a great deal of the game blindly before I realized that mousing over systems would show me the info I wanted to know about them in a popup window (what type of exchange I can do there, and how much of that exchange I can do) without having to warp to each and every system and just trial-and-error it all out. So a word to the wise, watch those popup highlights change, they contain lots of time-saving info.

Posted: May 30, 2014
												Note: This review might be biased as I am a huge fan of the 2D space combat genreOh my god do I love this game...even with over 70 hours (Edit: Now over 100 hours! Weee!) invested into it there are still high replayability, and that's some of the most engaging 100 hours I've had from start to end, just for the cheap price of 10USD. Amazing, simply amazing.The Pros-CustomizationWith 5 tiers (tiny, small, medium, large, huge) of ships (43 official ships in total, but there are mods that add in even more ships), each with a wide variety of slots to put different kinds of modules (weapons, boosters, subsystems etc.) as well as armor plates, shields/cloaks and reactors. The tech tree has 15 categories to invest into up to 10 times each, which is also nice. You can easily shape your fleet into killing machines with powers matched only by gluing 3 death stars together (or small cloaked dodgey ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s if you so desire).-ReplayabilityEach galaxy is randomly generated with multiple options and difficulty settings to further refresh your experience each run. The abundant amount of research also allows you to spec into another weapon type in the next run, allowing experimentation.-Reasonably Priced-Multiple Save Files and Autosaving-Modding-friendlyThe Cons-AIThe AI in this game will definitely not impress you. Even on the highest difficulty (insane) enemy AI behaviours don't deviate much from their normal cousins (they are, however, significantly more deadly.) The worst offender in this category is the friendly AI, as they are going to be your major source of fustration in the game, especially on higher difficulty settings. The commands you can give them aren't much either, but sufficient.-Death ScreamWhile thankfully, only your own units performs death screams occasionally when they die, the default death screams in this game are ear-shatteringly loud, and almost made my heart stop the first few times. You can counter this by sliding the unit chatter slide bar all the way to the left, while keeping most other sounds intact.-GlitchesWhile highly infrequent and never game-breaking, the game is also not well-polished enough, and glitches and bugs do pop in at times. Thankfully all I've encountered so far can be resolved by restarting the mission or reloading a save.Everything else (plot, music, art, graphics etc.) are relatively okay.ConclusionI highly recommend this game to fans of the genre, it is simply a masterpiece at its core with a few rough edges sold at an alluring price.

Posted: February 15, 2014
												A fun top down space adventure survival game. Run missions and and engage in piracy on a quest to the galactic core researching, salvaging, and stealing technology and ship types all along the way. It is great fun to tweak and optimize ship combinations and weapon loadouts, as well as dump excess crew into the void of space when the "zombies" breach your hull.

Posted: March 5, 2014
												Space pirates and zombies contains just what it sais on the package. You play as a space pirate and venture into danger. The gameplay feels nice and if you are playing on a low difficculty and huge galaxy the difficulty is not raising too much.If that is too boring then there are still some higher difficulties and some nice bounty hunter challenges.Certainly one of my favourite games of all times.

Posted: July 12, 2014
												So, I"ve got lots of very expensive big budget games in my little library. This little indie game is much better, and played far more often then many of them. It puts you in command of a little squad of ships, one of which you control directly. You hop around from system to system doing jobs for factions and trying to upgrade you ships. The ships are very configurable, and there are quite a few of them to play around with. All of this is very addictive. I've blinked and realised a couple of hours have flown by while I've been hopping accross the galaxy looking for that next level reactor part, or missle launcher, or new hull. The size of the galaxy is configured at the start of the game, and a huge galaxy is really huge. Looking back at that statement, it sounds funny, but it's true :). If you find the whole zombie craze very tired (like myself), don't be put off by the fact that it's in the title of this game. The zombies aren't really a "more brains" kind of thing, but more like the reavers in the movie Serenity.I've gotten a lot of value out of this game. I really don't think you can go wrong if you decide to pick it up. Oh, and they're working on spaz 2 right now. Yay :).

Posted: June 23, 2014
												I'm enjoying the heck out of this game. It's top-down 2D space combat primarily, with some exploration and slight RPG-ish aspects. The game features pretty good AI, has lots of outstanding ship customization options, a fun story, and it's got a pretty small hard drive footprint. SPAZ can get somewhat repetitive if you generate a large galaxy to explore, but a big galaxy also allows you plenty of areas to grind for levels or items to beat down a story mission or particular system. I've had a great time setting up my fleet for different play styles, such as all cargo/mining, area exploration, stealth, and having many many different enemy abuse options. There's a whole lot of trade-off going on with more advanced items not necessarily being automatically better in all circumstances, which I like very much. On top of all this goodness, there are zombies. Space zombies. So love/hate toward them. Check SPAZ out, it's a good one!

Posted: April 13, 2012
												Who doesn't like space, pirates, or zombies? A misleadingly simple-seeming game,  SPAZ is actually one hell of a, I want to say RTS? At first the story seems minor part of the game, something to give you a reason to pirate your way across the Milky Way and you become more concerned with blasting anything in your way. Posted: December 28, 2011
												I can't express how much fun this game is.  It's Starscape plus the ability to build and maintain a small squadron of AI squadmates.  You get to micromanage every hard point of every ship you control.  Researching new toys is based on XP which you gain by blowing things up and winning missions.  Enemy forces are constantly pushing back and retaking territory, opening up new missions which are dynamically created and never exhausted.  At time of writing, this is on sale for 2.50.Buy this game.

												GREAT game if you miss the old, top down veiw, space combat via lasers and missles shooting as yah steer with left and right and speed up and down with down and up frantically. Posted: September 15, 2014
												A little mundane at first; there's a lot of information to be conveyed (not information overload, but it pays to read the tutorial screens). The progression of weapons, armor, shields, ship types, and much more keep you playing till the end. Then, in my case starting over on a harder difficulty. There's a lot to like here; the one thing that's a little hard to get used to is the controls are relative to your ship, and not to the screen. I suspect it would have been too easy if they were relative to the screen, but finding that perfect balance of cargo hold, crew capacity and firepower at any given time is great fun.

Posted: February 2, 2012
												SPAZ is yet another game that the screenshots and trailers do no justice. The game was made by only two people.The universe you are set in is randomly generated and has a small amount of customization in size. The smaller the universe, the harder the difficulty between each galaxy. The bigger the universe, the longer the overall game and the more stretched out resources are. The game tells you not to do your first playthrough on the hardest difficulty. I immediately went and ignored this because I love a good challenge.And boy does SPAZ deliver. You have up to three of your own ships in play at once. You can manually control one of the three ships at any time and the AI will take over the other two. The combat can go beyond mindlessly killing at times in the harder difficulties and thought is needed to plan out what you are going to do. Getting a game over is rare but progression is also challenging.Good for casual and hardcore players. I'd write more but I've run out of room.

Posted: September 26, 2013
												This game is a treat if you like to nerd out by customizing your in-game toys. I recommend playing on a fairly challenging difficulty and playing a very large game (as in, the largest). I powered through a small, not-too-challenging game and then could not stomach a second go at it and I am sad because of it.The often requested feature of multi-player support would make this a true gem of a game. I would spend endless hours playing this with friends were that made a reality.As it is, tweaking out the ever growing ships and dialing them in exactly to your preferred methods of destruction is a great treat. Playing with "unorthodox" load-outs can be a game in itself and the game on a whole is being continually expanded upon and improved by a couple of independent developers.All in all a great game and absolutely worth owning, there just is not much more to say about it!

Posted: December 22, 2013
												I would recommend this game for fans of the genre. It's not for everyone, but definitely a pearl of it's kind. A huge galaxy, a lot of ships with even more modules to customize.The story line is OK. It makes sense in the sense that it carriers th games progression, but it wasn't engaging enough to get me back to playing. What got me back was the urge to finally explore all systems, find all blueprints, max my stats and kick zombie♥♥♥♥♥The game has it's downsides, of course. For example the huge galaxy in the standard setting. While it forces you to engage in fight so you level up, you just visit most systems once while passing through. The weapons aren't balanced, some types are rather weak even when upgraded all the way. Weapons also have a fire rate cap, so more weapons will not always result in moe DPS. I also would have wished for a way to change the control from relative to absolute but after a couple of hours I adapted quite well.Overall a "good" game which has it's downsides but still manages to bring a fresh wind to the genre!

Posted: February 15, 2014
												-Tactical starship combat with a small fleet of 3-4 highly customizeable ships.-Tech/skill tree with unlockable component and ship blueprints.-RPG styled leveling (read:grinding) system.-Macro game featuring a galaxy map with (mildly important) strategic choices regarding which sectors to clear/defend and which mission types to take next.This game is a blast if you love fast-paced space/starship combat and endlessly customizing/tweaking equipment and skill trees.Worth every single cent at $9.99.  I would absolutely recommend you do not pass this up if you see it on sale.And if you like it, /please/ spread the word and help promote awesome indie games like this one and save us from the bland mediocrity of huge media corporations!

Posted: June 4, 2013
												One of the nicest indie game I've ever played. You destroy ship to get XP and ressources to buy bigger, better ships to be able to destroy more ships. Each planetary system has 2 factions, and you can choose one faction or the other in each system. Later in the game, you can destroy some zombie ships, and it gives a little more challenge to the game. There is even bounty hunters that are not part of any factions and that can hunt you down if the bounty on your head is big enough.There is one big problem in this game : there is a time when you need to grind a lot. I've played 24 hours and I still haven't finished the game because I need to grind the XP and the ressources to go further in the game.It's truly a good game and I had a lot of fun playing it but it takes a lot of time to finish.

Posted: December 22, 2013
												I could spend all day exploring star system after star system in SPAZ.  Every minute is full of crazy events like fighting whole squads of military ships, to crazier things like collecting waste to produce food (you read that right!).  But with the zombies along with an already amazing adventure, this game deserves at least one playthrough (but will probably get many more).

Posted: February 16, 2014
												Great game. Top down two dimensional view arcade-y space sim-lite. A mouthful! Side with the UTA (the established military forces) or the civilians of countless star systems while keeping safe from zombies and bounty hunters in your quest to the core of the universe. Power up your ships, find blueprints and build new ones, customize them with a variety of weapons and systems, or maybe just mine asteroids until your eyes bleed. It's your choice, and it's deep enough to be engaging but not so deep as to completely ward off newbies.

Posted: May 12, 2014
												Enjoyment can be found finding and upgrading ships.The cost is on par with content. I believe this game is a good investment.

Posted: April 26, 2014
												This is one of my favorite indie games on Steam - a true gem. Even though it's made by a two-man team, this is an awesome 2D space combat game. It's not laden with overly complicated interfaces and rule systems like a lot of strategy games, yet has enough customizability and complexity to keep the player engaged. Ignore the story, and focus on configuring your ships. My 40 hours on a single playthrough is proof of how much fun I had. Some may find the combat repetitive eventually, but I found the steady trickle of new weapons enough to keep me invested. I love this game and am very excited for the sequel!

Posted: July 12, 2014
												I ended up putting in way more hours than I ever thought I would in playing this game. All in good fun, though. It's a good top down space shooter with a lot to do, some quirky humor, and several different ways of playing (though maybe only a few work best in Insane difficulty -- canons and stealth are your friend until you build up the tech to face things head on). It can be a bit grindy at times, especially when you get to the Zombies part of the title, as you'll want to acquire powerful tech and ship blueprints to deal with them (and this goes double especially on Insane difficulty). But, if you get into it, you'll barely notice all the time pass until you've suddenly put in over 100 hours. A good, well-put together game at a cheap price. Worth the full price. A no brainer when on sale. :)

Posted: September 13, 2014
												"If any of the hostages give you any lip, throw em out the airlock with the rest of the trash." Space Slaver Sim 2011, 10/10 would buy again.Seriously though, I regret not picking this up before. Its a 2D isometric space ship pew pew game that kind of tends to lead you along with the promise of new and better ships and upgrades, but along the way teaches you the complexity of said upgrades and combat. The only downfall I'd say it has is the repetitive ambient chatter, and the godawful character faces/avatars, but then again it was made by just two people. I'm going to put a lot more hours into this. Highly recommended.

Posted: July 25, 2014
												Space Pirates and Zombies. such an amazing game just amazing the amount of ships there are is broad with each ship being diffrent in its own way allowing you to add diffrent types of weapons and utilitys like drones and tractor beams allowing you to mine when you need currency of which there are two credits and goons which can be spent on diffrent things such as items and passing points without violence, the game can be difficult or easy depending on who you ally with and what ships you use and which star you go to, over all the game is a very fun and enjoyable expansive game which i would highly recommend.

												Brilliant indie game, great fun although it does get a bit boring towards the end once you overlevel so far, the combat becomes repetitive and predictable. Still worth a look at though if you like the space genre and indie game. Think 21st Century space invaders!

Posted: April 13, 2014
												This is like that old classic Escape Velocity, but on steroids, WITH ZOMBIES! Total awesomeness with a massive amount of gameplay for the price!  Everything in SPAZ is done well, graphics, controls, gameplay, storyline, just a really great job all round by the developers.

Posted: October 10, 2014
												I've been hooked on this for a while, it's easy to pick up and play with just enough complexity to keep you going. I find myself in that "one more turn" mentality. It's an upgrade-based game, and that does mean a bit of grind, which may seem like a dirty word to use, but it is the sort of 'waves of enemies' and 'perfect your game' kind of deal. It definitely doesn't feel like a chore, and stays fun and addictive.Big applause to the devs for breaking up gameplay style in how the chapters work. This mechanic kept the gameplay fresh and exciting!

Posted: December 4, 2013
												Space Pirates and Zmbies is a top down space shoot em up. Having not completed anything other than easy or medium, try not taking this review into account for the harder difficulty settings.The game itself starts off slow when you are given the worst of the worst ships named the Short Bus. This thing's beam cannot kill pretty much anything. But new and better ships start coming along very soon with the player going from the worst laser ever to lasers and cannons. (For the cannon think of a rifle in those games where you can hold down the trigger or whatever, where it shoots at a moderate speed.)Even though the guns get better some poeple may still think of them as utter crap as the better stuff comes in much later.Also new players may find the shooting with both lasers and cannons very frustrating and have the A.I do most of the work.The game also features 3 resources. rez, goons and data.  Rez a brightly coloured space rock that doubles as the currency of the game  as well as the raw resource that you build your ships with. The game does a very good job of allowing you to collect rez and not loose it. The enemy ships, you will be fighting, nearly always drop a nice chunk of rez for you to loot whereas your ships deposit your supllies of rez into a large pool that you (mostly) cannot lose.The next resource is goons. Goons are workers/slaves/mercenaries that you pick up in escape pods floating around in space. Picking them up ads them to your goon pool much like your rez pool. Unlike rez, goons are used to keep your ship in tip top shape once it is flying, rather then build it. The amount of goons that join you when you pick them up depends on your crew skill.Your crew skill is an indication of how well you keep oder/how much they like you. At first this skill will be very low, level zero in fact. At this low level most of the crew get thrown out of the air lock of your ships instead of being crewed. This could be a bit frustrating as 6 crew can suddenly turn into 3 crew as half are chucked out the air lock for being troble makers.But there is usally so many crew pods, you rarely have this problem.Then there's the last resource data. Data are little bits of trashed computer parts and what not, scattered about the place after you trash a bunch of your foes. Data is unique in the fact that it can generate itself as well as goons.  Every time you collect a certain amount of data, starting at about 100 (eazy to do as you collect it in tens at a time) you clone a certain amount of your current goons into new ones.Data also allows you to progress along a tech tree of sorts as each time you level up you gain 3 points to spend. The points can be spent in things such as shields thrusters or drones. Each certain amount of points you put into a certain category upgrades it a bit. And with the best weapons upgraded to the full level (10) or even a little below it (8) you can blast and melt your way through whatever even looks at you funny without a care.Next up(ALERT! ALERT! SPOILERS INCOMING!) Zombies. Zombies come into the game at a very late point which is a bit weird considering the game is called space pirates and zombies. They can be a bit of a pain if faced without the right equipment, for example without a point defence system (a little red cricle that shoots a red laser at incoming zombies and missiles) they can swarm your ship, take down its sheilds, kill its crew and infect it, turning what was once your best ship, against you. Another slightly annoying thing they do, is spawn the very tiny ships called ticks that, once injured enough, will fly faster then you can to the edge of the screen causing you to retreat back to your mother ship and then warp to a new place, rather than just warping, as you cannot warp when there are enemies nearby.2nd last on this reveiw is bounty hunters. Bounty hunters can be a HUGE pain in the backside as they track whoever you kill, causing your bounty to rack up. Once this bounty is high enough it will cause the bounty hunters to come after you for that sweet bounty on your head. If not prepared properly these guys can wreck you and your ships pretty fast. That's why I recommend for any new players to turn them down to low in the starting settings. This will make sure you are not getting smoked by them every time you warp to a new sector, but also allow you to find out what they are like and how they work.Lastly are space stations. Space stations are big shielded things that stay in one place. But be careful who you anger in this game. As flying to a space station, when either it is to high a level for you or you are to low a level for it, can leave you with no rez or ships if it blows them all up. Also a tip for a mid level mission, in which I got stuck on for a while, where you have to shoot a space station untill it gives up its reactor for you. My tip is if you can't beat it at first just grind a bit of low level stuff first. Trust me, at first it may be boring but it defenitly is worth it when you beat the station and move on to the better parts of the game.Well, that just about wraps up this review and my few last words are: A good game for most poeple, but better if you're patient and don't mind a bit of a grind.

Posted: January 13, 2014
												As the Britishism goes, "Does exactly what it says on the tin"You get space pirates and you get zombies.Somehow this genre jumping game manages to capture real time space battles, resource management and zombies well.Granted, the game suffers a bit from trying to do too much at once, but I would much rather a game try too much than not enough.3.5/5

												Excellent game that few people seem to  know about.

												you cannot possibly get a better deal than SPAZ for 2 bucks!!  BUY IT NOW!!!  Fun, easy, good-looking space combat and a surprisingly in-depth campaign make for a ton of fun for a low low price.

This could be a bit frustrating as 6 crew can suddenly turn into 3 crew as half are chucked out the air lock for being troble makers.But there is usally so many crew pods, you rarely have this problem.Then there's the last resource data. Data are little bits of trashed computer parts and what not, scattered about the place after you trash a bunch of your foes. Data is unique in the fact that it can generate itself as well as goons.  Every time you collect a certain amount of data, starting at about 100 (eazy to do as you collect it in tens at a time) you clone a certain amount of your current goons into new ones.Data also allows you to progress along a tech tree of sorts as each time you level up you gain 3 points to spend. The points can be spent in things such as shields thrusters or drones. Each certain amount of points you put into a certain category upgrades it a bit. And with the best weapons upgraded to the full level (10) or even a little below it (8) you can blast and melt your way through whatever even looks at you funny without a care.Next up(ALERT! ALERT! SPOILERS INCOMING!) Zombies. Zombies come into the game at a very late point which is a bit weird considering the game is called space pirates and zombies. They can be a bit of a pain if faced without the right equipment, for example without a point defence system (a little red cricle that shoots a red laser at incoming zombies and missiles) they can swarm your ship, take down its sheilds, kill its crew and infect it, turning what was once your best ship, against you. Another slightly annoying thing they do, is spawn the very tiny ships called ticks that, once injured enough, will fly faster then you can to the edge of the screen causing you to retreat back to your mother ship and then warp to a new place, rather than just warping, as you cannot warp when there are enemies nearby.2nd last on this reveiw is bounty hunters. Bounty hunters can be a HUGE pain in the backside as they track whoever you kill, causing your bounty to rack up. Once this bounty is high enough it will cause the bounty hunters to come after you for that sweet bounty on your head. If not prepared properly these guys can wreck you and your ships pretty fast. That's why I recommend for any new players to turn them down to low in the starting settings. This will make sure you are not getting smoked by them every time you warp to a new sector, but also allow you to find out what they are like and how they work.Lastly are space stations. Space stations are big shielded things that stay in one place. But be careful who you anger in this game. As flying to a space station, when either it is to high a level for you or you are to low a level for it, can leave you with no rez or ships if it blows them all up. Also a tip for a mid level mission, in which I got stuck on for a while, where you have to shoot a space station untill it gives up its reactor for you. My tip is if you can't beat it at first just grind a bit of low level stuff first. Trust me, at first it may be boring but it defenitly is worth it when you beat the station and move on to the better parts of the game.Well, that just about wraps up this review and my few last words are: A good game for most poeple, but better if you're patient and don't mind a bit of a grind.

Posted: May 25, 2016
												This is a game with a great core gameplay loop - load up a couple of ships with various items and fly them around frantically through a swarm of other ships blowing stuff up. The action-oriented 2D combat is great fun, with surprisingly great physics and object interaction for such a seemingly simple game. The fact that the plot and the elements in play radically changes halfway through the game is a bonus, and works great even though the zombies are spoiled by the game's actual title.There are a few issues I had with the game though. Grinding for resources and data can be quite a hassle - the less you grind, the harder the combat is, because your equipment simply won't be as good. Updating your tech RPG-style is really compelling, but unfortunately not every tech is created equal. Techs all cost the same, but it seems clear to me that investing 50+ skillpoints in, say, Hull strength or Shields is vastly preferable to investing the same amount of points in something like Bombs (a really specific type of weapon) or Crew (only situationally useful). Maybe this depends on playstyle, but I tried investing in things like Subsystems or Launchers at first and found the benefits just weren't as tangible.Also, for a game that probably takes even experts 30+ hours to complete, the fairly small number of mission types gets old fairly quickly.That said, the core gameplay is really fun and made it worth it for me, and the sense of progress you get teching up and defeating fleets that would have smeared you to a paste several hours earlier is tangible and rewarding. If you've got a lot of time and like a simple 2D action game, give this a shot!

Posted: May 16, 2016
												Do not let the price of this rare gem fool you, Because the content this game can offer is well worth more! SPAZ is a fantastic, well-made game developed by only two people who had a dream and made it reality, Creating a stepping stone for others to do the same. After 300+ hours into this game, Here's my experience so far.PROS: 1. What initially brought me to this game was how alive it felt, With something always going on around every corner of the galaxy. There are many events and little side-missions that make it feel like it's a living, breathing environment2. While on the surface the mechanics look simple, there is a surprising amount of depth put into how you can personally tailor and customize your ships to your own liking, Giving you the chance to get creative and make many different layouts and strategies on how you want to play.3. The exploration, With the choice of either a minimum of 150 stars or a maximum of 300 stars, You can set the pace at which you play the game to your own standards. Regardless of what you choose, It takes a considerable time to explore each and every different system, Giving you a reasonable space to scavenge for tech that you may need.4.The combat, the main focus of this game, Is very engrossing and addictive. The controls are tight, The gameplay is fluid and it's all easy to pickup, But hard to master. From blasting your enemies away with cannons to steadily melting them to scrap from far away, There's plenty of options for you to take down your enemies. (Or civilians, if you're not in the most merciful mood!)CONS:1. The game can become very repetitive, With most side-missions being recycled, And many tasks needing to be done in order to progress with reputation.2. It can feel very grindy, especially early on in the game when you need to farm resources and levels if you ever get stuck on a quest.3.  The Zombies in the game can become very tedious to clear out later on in the game,  This game has brought me tons of priceless joy, I hope I had shared some of that experience with you all, Because even with all that I said, I still can't express or put into words how much I love this game, Thank you for reading this far, Have a pleasant day.

Posted: January 4, 2014

Posted: July 3, 2016
												This is a great game to sink hours upon hours into, still only got to the middle, but I am hooked, as simple as it is, building ships and fitting them with weapons you grinded for and blowing up enemy ships has some retro-ish vibes that scratch an itch that modern games just don't give you anymore.SPAZ is kind of like a forgiving rouge like, it has many elements of a rogue like, but you don't loose much if you die, if you have ever felt like going all in guns blazing in a rouge like, but went the safe route because you didn't want to loose your stuff? SPAZ will scratch that itch.The "cling cling cling" sound of missiles detaching from your ship, the radio chatter, getting used to your new customized ship's drag while you whiz around firing and dogging enemy fire is such a satisfying experience.Also its nice that you have multiple ships to command and can switch to with ease, you can build your fleet in such a way that is very specific to your tactics, which would not work if the ships are controlled by AI.It does get tedious to grind for materials, but not to the point its annoying.I actually bought SPAZ 2 before this, but I don't plan to move my way up to it just yet, SPAZ 1 is just too addicting to let go.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2013
												The first thing you'll notice about SPAZ is the customization.  Do you want to play in a massive galaxy?  Do you want to be starved for technology?  Do you want to turn off the Bounty Hunters entirely?  You can do that.  The customization of course applies to the many different ship types, such as what armament to use and even the level-up system, so maybe you want to focus on shields first or maybe you like the punch of cannons so you focus on those.  SPAZ is not an RTS, but it has some elements, like having resources to manage (albeit it's just REZ for money and Goons for slave labor), which you use for the production of your up to four ships for your small fleet, and both are used for the purchase of new weapons blueprints.  You also have to maintain relations between you and two factions, or three with the included And Bounty Hunters expansion.  Do you fight the UTA for the benefit of the CIVs, or do you backstab both groups for your own profit?  This is complicated by the fact that every sector has its own faction relation to you, and anything you do in one sector has no effect on the rest.  But that's where the Bounty Hunters come in.  There are light RPG elements too, mainly in how you spend your upgrade points in what trees to bolster your ships and enable the use of better equipment.  There is a good variety of missions, like destroy X many crates without being seen, or destroying a big ice meteor before it plows through a research station, or the simple "kill everyone of this faction" and everything rewards you with money, people, and typically a change in faction relation.  Or maybe some new equipment, or even a little bit of story.  The game changes pretty drastically during the final chapter, though you are given advance warning before this point.  And you don't even have to do missions all the time.  You can just pop by the mining colony and chip away at meteors for money...only for one of the groups you ticked off to suddenly warp in and you're now scrambling to send away your mining ships for battle ones.  There's a good bit of stuff to do and collect and kill in this game.  I especially like the fact that you can custom-tailor your experience to start, though there's no way to change that once you've started.  Battles are oftentimes difficult and relying on your AI allies is an exercise in frustration, but learning the nuances of the weapons and how much impact the different gear you can equip to every ship is essential for victory.  Do you want a massive battlecruiser with extremely strong shields and armor?  Or maybe a tiny ship with extreme speed for hit-and-run tactics?  Why not both?  You can only directly control one ship at a time, but the ability to swap at any time might be essential to keep everyone alive and to keep your coffers full.And this game has no discrete "game over" condition, as you can always fight back from zero even in the final chapter, though it will be tedious and difficult to rebuild your fleet when you've no REZ nor Goons.  And while you're slowly chipping away at stray rocks in the Short Bus after a massive defeat, you'll be thinking up a plan to exact your revenge.  It will be glorious.  So yeah.  SPAZ is a game I like.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 11, 2013
												This is a great game. If you know Star control 2 then this is basically a tribute to that, but then with an ARPG twist. It's a bit like Diablo in space. You can explore a very attractive looking 2d universe and shoot lots of interesting and increasingly powerful spaceships and then you can build them yourself and customize them with weapons and upgrades.The story has some interesting twists to keep it fresh and you will feel a great sense of progression. In a nutshell, this game is awesome. It was developed by a small indie company so it is sometimes a bit rough around the edges but the gameplay is very solid and if you like space shooters with progression then this should keep you busy for many, many hours. I highly recommend it.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2013
												SPAZ is like the classic game of Asteroids, except on crack.  Seriously, this overhead shooter has everything you want in a space combat action game.  The controls are accurate to being in space,  the weapons are all balanced really well, as are the ships!  You grow more powerful over time, and discover new tech.  The story, while not the best, its still well thought.  There are even mod tools available on their game forums.  Most importantly, its fun to play.  Unlike many games in this generation, this one doesn't feel like a second job.

content:
Posted: October 9, 2015
												Would love to love it, but the game doesn't love me back.It's fun and easy until you reach act 3. Then it is just punishing and takes all fun away. Cannons maxed, shields maxed, lots of point im secondary system, almost no points in unused systems... get wrecked by AI ships. Well, sometimes it's still pretty ok, but then you have two enemy ships with equal tech as yourself, but you don't need to know a lot about the game that this won't work.Searching for answers about how to deal with this brings up countless players having the same issue.Trying other stragtegies is no fun because of the random nature of the game and the fact that losses will end up in grinding money to get on track again. Add to this that every respec costs tons of data/XP and stops your progress for hours.Very disappointed.

content:

												If you were playing FTL and thought to yourself, "This is great, but I need... MORE" Then Spaz is the game for you.If you were playing Gratuitous Space Battles and thought to yourself, "This is boring, I need... MORE" Again, Spaz is the game for you.I want to stop playing it, but I can't. I have to conquer the galaxy, pirate-style. Incredibly addicting, and like FTL, ignore any and all dialogue. number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 15, 2014
												I'd seen SPAZ go on sale a few times but never really paid much attention until it went on sale for $2 and I had a spare bit of change in my Steam wallet.Best $2 that I've ever spent, unless you could the 3 sausage rolls for a pound (about 2 dollars more or less) from Greg's bakery.I am a huge fan of Star Control and never thought that any game could live up to the standard that it set way back in the days of the Sega Megadrive. I was wrong. Whether it was inspired by SC or not, I don't know, but if you liked SC and want a modernized version of it, SPAZ is the best that there is.If you haven't played Star Control, I will give you the gist of what SPAZ is. Spaz is a top down space shooter. You are in command of a band of Space pirates. With humble beginnings, you can gradually work your way up and become more powerful, reverse engineering ships that you destroy, gathering resources to build researched ships and to buy blueprints for new modules to go on them. You can fly into combat with a small fleet of AI controlled allies, toggling between the ships at will to command for yourself.If you like games with depth and action and don't care about graphics, I fully recommend this game. I got it for a bargain, but even it's full price is well worth the expense. A must have.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 19, 2012
												I picked this up in the winter sale and I quite enjoy it. I remember playing a game called Star Control when I was a kid and SPAZ seems very keen to evoke those memories.The bulk of the game is spent carrying out missions (i.e. quests) which will reward currency and/or reputation with each system's faction. Speaking of which, each system has two sides: UTA (Empire) and Civilians (Rebels). You don't always have to butter up one or the other, and which side you'll have to♥♥♥♥♥♥off will vary from system to system. It's very much up to you how and where you want to go questing, but the levelling process can feel a bit grindy.The combat is fun but not overly deep, and things can get a bit repetitive. I've put 30 hours into it so far and I've only really just got into the meat of the campaign I think. At a sale price, I'd say it's worth it. I wouldn't be disappointed to buy it at 50% off so anything else is a bonus.p.s. If you're on the fence, TRY THE DEMO. It's a good taster.

												If you got a slower computer (Pentium 4 2.4ghz) go for Missles and 1 ship to take out sheilds. The Homing missles are the best. They Just wipe out just about everything, Hunter SIM. So when the game play gets really choppy ~1fps, the missles still hit their targets, no need to worry about aiming turrets or cannons or beams, or have the auto aim not hit things. Beat game last part was surpisingly easy. Guess I'll go back to save before that and try and destory a bounty hunter base or all of them.

												Reminds me a lot of Star Control II in terms of gameplay mechanics, but with more overarching strategy and customisation going on. The opening blurb says that they wanted to make games that they don't see a lot of any more compared to days gone by and I think they did a fine job of it. 												Easy to learn & use the controls, and while not TOO deep in features, the ones that are available are well done & easy to incorporate into your game. number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 24, 2015
												I did not find the combat enjoyable one tiny bit.  The ship handling is sloppy.  The ships have tons of momentum and terrible acceleration so changing directions is a pain and takes way too long.  You spend most of your time flying past your enemies and missing your shots, then trying to turn around for another pass, only to miss again, and then turn around again, and so on and so forth.  Actually killing anything took way too long and was simply more trouble and aggravation than it was worth.  I was mislead by an idiotic comment by a curator, describing the game as "arcadey", it's anything but.  Do not expect to get your space combat thrills here.

content:
Posted: March 11
												Grind, wait, grind, wait... You grind though the galaxy. The same simple fights to collect technology and experience to get stronger. If your resources get low you camp at a mining station for some minutes. Enough time to cook or go to toilet.In the late game you start parking in front of your enemies. My last fights had a boss I was camping 10 minutes in front of him and a visited stations where I just waited for some minutes, because the enemies are faster fleeing than you can follow. They flee one minute and then travel back one minute...My tech was maxed and I tried different builds. This game could have been a good 5 hour game, but it is stretched to 40+.

content:
Posted: January 4, 2013
												This game is a very interesting type I've never really tried in the past. It's based on this group who end up having their main station destroyed and reduced to the lowest tech and losing all tech, but you manage to have some to make ships and continue to claim blueprints through the game.As the titles suggest it's in space and you fight against Pirates and Zombies as wll as military and civilian. You can either do jobs for either sides to gain Rez (currency) to buy schematics for new ships or weapons. You can also gain tech points for research into using better weapons, shields and armour.It's certainly a very long game with a lot of grind, but you don't have to buy stuff from space stations as if you are well enough equipped you can destroy their station and steal all they have for free, but it only depends on the balance between how many times you've died and what you get out of it as the payment for making your ship can be very big if you spent a lot of money to make your Ship massive.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 16, 2016
												I played this all the way through (offline) back in the day. It's strange because the shallow gameplay would normally cause me to give it a thumbs down, but there is something about this game that got me totally hooked and I've recently played it halfway through again. Now that I've come here to write a review I've discovered that SPAZ2 has just gone to early access and the video for it it making my heart thump already. Anyway, back to my review...Cons (none of which matter to me)The game universe is enormous but to be honest all a bit samey. You have to complete endless tasks to gain the technology and resources to upgrade your ships, but these tasks mostly involve battling enemies which is really the be-all and end-all of this game. In theory you're supposed to tailor your ships/weapons to the task at hand, but in practice it doesn't really seem to matter, you just equip the best weapons you can find and use them for everything. It's not the most intellectually challenging game.Con (which does matter)There is a storyline to this game, with an ending. After it had finished, to my dismay, I discovered that it was impossible to go back and play some more with the massive battleships I had worked for hours on end to build up. Bear this in mind before you tackle the final task, or make a data backup!ProsIt's all about building bigger and better ships with more and more firepower and watching the battle mayhem. Especially towards the end of the game when huge battleships are blasting each other to smithereens it's a sight to behold, and the amazing thing is that all this glorious graphics action doesn't seem to lag or stutter at all, it's smooth as silk.Now enough of this, I'm off to buy SPAZ2!

content:
Posted: September 3, 2011
												This is very reminiscent of older space exploration games I used to play (whose names I can't remember which is why I picked this up on a whim). You start off piloting a flying trash can and through the tutorial fix it up enough to control a small fleet. There is some seriously deep customization with your ships. With carriers that can support their own miniature fleets to turret covered behemoths that can shoot 360°, both the pea-shooters you get at the beginning and the imperial destroyers you get near the end all have their uses throughout the whole game. There are some balancing issues with weapons (cannons are a swiss-army knife that destroy everything while missiles are useless late game because of point blank defense systems, etc.) and framerate slowdown once the zombies joins the fray, but patches are being worked on to fix these issues and add more content.If you enjoy 4X games, this $15 variation is worth your money just for the nostalgia rush.

content:
Posted: September 21, 2014
												Frustrating, tedious, hard.  Sometimes SPAZ makes me want to eat my keyboard at times.Yet I come back to it.  Why?  Why?  Why?Update: The frustration outweighed the fun, finally.  I stopped coming back to this game.  Too grindy later in the game.Actually, I know why.  The game doesn't have the most balanced mechanics, nor does the difficulty ramp up all that smoothly (more like, brick-walls on you if you aren't careful).  But it's a 2D space combat simulator with a teeny little bit of RPG tossed in for good measure and a heavy exploration element, and by God's Bones, they dun make games like this no more.There's lots of ships to unlock and lots of goodies to toss onto said ships, so at least if you feel bored using one sort of build you can swap it for another.If you put in lots of hours in games like StarControl, Escape Velocity: Nova, StarFlight and Solar Winds, then buy SPAZ and enjoy it.  If you have no idea what any of those games are, then you might want to pass.  Then again, it's on sale at times for just a few bucks, so what do you have to lose?  Aside from a few bucks.Pros:* Nobody makes these kinds of games anymore, OH WAIT, they did!* Lots of ships and weapons/upgrades to discover.* Big universe to explore.* Nice visuals and sound effects.Cons:* Big universe to explore.  Becomes tedious after a while since systems must be unlocked one at a time.* Chunky and slow during big space battles, especially later in the game with lots of ______'s flying about spewing chunks.  (*Spoilers!)* Space battles can end up near-stalemate battles of attrition, which take a long time to resolve.* Less story-telling versus games like EV:Nova, etc.

content:
Posted: February 21, 2016
												Space Pirates and Zombies (SPAZ) is a top-down, 2D space pirate combat game where you explore the galaxy completing quests, finding resources, and upgrading your ships.  There is a story here, but in between heavy grinding sessions, I forgot what was actually going on.  Overall, the game is fun and the combat is exciting, but I did get frustrated many times after getting thoroughly whooped on the battlefield (battle-space?).  Hopefully SPAZ 2 will be released soon with improved features and gameplay.PROS+ Controls are intuitive once you get used to them (WASD oriented towards mouse pointer)+ Combat is mostly fun and exciting+ Large number of ship upgrades and modules to purchase and find+ Customizing ships is fun (weapons, armor, subsystems, specialists)+ Resources (currency, data, and manpower) are plentiful+ Each star system has factions to interact with via quests and events (but...see CON)CONS- Mothership can only be upgraded after certain story missions (required for most other upgrades)- Grinding is necessary to advance- Most missions ultimately feel the same (battle after battle after battle...)- Since faction respect doesn't carry between systems, it feels rather unimportant long-term- Needs autosave function

content:
Posted: December 30, 2011
												There is a bit of a learning curve up front, but this game is a gem once you get going. Along the lines of Starscape (which I've previously recommended), you are gradually exploring the galaxy using small ships deployed from a larger mothership. As you go, you will develop relationships with local civilian or military factions, fighting missions for them to gain experience and advance your research. Upgrade all aspects of your mothership and deployable crafts, and iteratively gain the ability to explore more of the galaxy. Oh yes, and there's zombies, too. Good times.

												I traded a GayMod steam gift for this game and let me tell you that it was well worth it.This game is sort of like an online game i've played for like 7 years: Darkorbit except that spaz is a singleplayer game unlike darkorbit, in darkorbit you are overwhelmed by cheaters left and right.What i like about the game:- Really RPG like, i LOVE RPG's- You have to plan out a strategy before you go guns ablazin or else you'll end up mining for rez for the next half hour to repair your fleet- Doesn't take me 5 hours to beat the game, i can see myself sinking 20+ hours into this gameWhat i don't like about the game:- Low amount and repetitive missions- Not much to do except whoop some♥♥♥♥♥and mine rez- The solar system is BIG but not big enough, WE NEED BIGGER!!!!!- Small amount of ship classes you can choose from- Small amount of weapons you can choose fromOther thoughts:It'll be REALLY cool if you could upgrade your weapons, for example having a level 1 mining lazer and paying to get it to level 2 so it might be 1% faster or have a longer burst. Over all this is a REALLY fun game, highly recommend it.

content:
Posted: April 25, 2016
												This won't be a review that shows all the facts, the pros and cons. It's rather going to be my personal love letter for this game. I picked up Space Pirates and Zombies a few years ago, not long after the release. Since then it really found a straight way into my gamer heart, making me play it again every few months. I can say without doubt, that this game is among my Top 3 favourite games of all time!Who didn't want to fly around in big space ship discovering the universe when they were young? SPAZ made this dream come true for me... at least on the screen. It is the perfect mix of flying around, discovering, building up your small fleet, fancy and colourful explosions, tactics, ship management, looting and a simple but funny told story, which matches the title. There's always this next blueprint you wanna get in order to upgrade you ships. There's always this next planet or galaxy you wanna visit to find out what treasures it withholds from you. There's always this next mission you want to complete, this next ship you want to destroy, this next achievement you want to achieve. And just like this hours passed by and I experienced how evenings turned into nights turned into mornings, until I was finally too tired to continue with the adventure of my small space fleet.In the end I highly recommend this game to everybody felt a little of the joy and excitement while reading this. Even if you won't get as much out of it as I did, I can still pretty much promise you quite some hours of fun. And if this game is on sale, it really is a must buy!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 21, 2016
												Space Pirates and Zombies (SPAZ) is a top-down, 2D space pirate combat game where you explore the galaxy completing quests, finding resources, and upgrading your ships.  There is a story here, but in between heavy grinding sessions, I forgot what was actually going on.  Overall, the game is fun and the combat is exciting, but I did get frustrated many times after getting thoroughly whooped on the battlefield (battle-space?).  Hopefully SPAZ 2 will be released soon with improved features and gameplay.PROS+ Controls are intuitive once you get used to them (WASD oriented towards mouse pointer)+ Combat is mostly fun and exciting+ Large number of ship upgrades and modules to purchase and find+ Customizing ships is fun (weapons, armor, subsystems, specialists)+ Resources (currency, data, and manpower) are plentiful+ Each star system has factions to interact with via quests and events (but...see CON)CONS- Mothership can only be upgraded after certain story missions (required for most other upgrades)- Grinding is necessary to advance- Most missions ultimately feel the same (battle after battle after battle...)- Since faction respect doesn't carry between systems, it feels rather unimportant long-term- Needs autosave function

content:
Posted: January 14, 2015
												I HATE HATE      HATE HATEHATE          Trying to learn new complex games that are a really great but it's fun.  What I mean is that I just learned how to play Project Zomboid(coincidence, not on a zombie kick), FTL and a couple others and I wanna know how to play instantly because my brain is about to explode.   I Just got the basics down on this and got through my first gate and did a couple side missions and can tell this is gonna be a great one(game that is) and I'm going to compare it to FTL and hope to not get yelled at and because I just wanna say that it's kinda like FTL but much more better because graphix and seems to be deeper in stuff and mechanics and well everything.   9.5/10 so far.  I guess -.5 for the tutorial skipping on a few much needed pointers/tips. I highly recommend reading and/or watching some tutorials.    There is one on youtube that I watched where a dude plays through the beginning but doesn't do a great job explaining what each thing is so it's probably best to find other info out or play the demo and then watch his vid like I did   Yeah, I did the demo for an hour and kinda kept it in the back of my head that dying was ok because it wasn't the real game yet, so this may be a good strategy for others. Also S.P.A.Z. 2 is coming out soon I think and hoping I get enough play in here to help me there.    Hope this helps and that the "and's" were a bit humorous and not annoying(eek...)

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 20, 2013
												This game has provided me 122 hours of entertainment. Which is an absurd amount for many games of its type out right now. Granted, I never want to play it again due to both doing all there was to do (within reason) and being completely obsessive about looking at every ship, every part, and every configuration thereof. It has this weird feel about it that makes me remember the "games you can't find anymore" as the authors call it. Without actually being able to call to mind what games it refers to exactly.The art is quite unique and detailed. The character portraits are randomly generated for specialists which can generate some amusing stuff. The plot-relevant portraits are made using the same dada-style copy & paste technique that the specialists do, just not randomly generated. It's pretty charming really.

												I quite liked this game- the playstyle, the graphics, even the atrocious, cheesy writing. As a quick aside, they apparently even got that TotalBiscuit fellow to do a great deal of exposition, and while he’s not the greatest narrator of all time, it does lend a certain gravitas gravy to the cheese. Kudos all around.However, once the zombies get introduced, I quickly lost interest. I was actually rather looking forward to playing as a space zombie, which doesn’t appear to be a thing, but more than that there seems to be a distinct lack of good ways to deal with them. I’m sure there’s something I’m missing, but I take umbrage at having to do research on a game to defeat zombies- I, like general use of zombies these days, am a little tired…

content:

												SPAZ is a top-down space shoot-em-up that has pretty graphics and some nice RPG/upgrade elements for a variety of unlockable spacecraft.  It's a great game to play when you need to kill some time, but the repetitive missions keep it from being much more than that.  However, SPAZ is a great companion to FTL: Faster Than Light;  where FTL requires you to adequately manage infrastructures amidst turn-based combat, SPAZ does that♥♥♥♥♥♥for you, and lets you just kill things in real-time until you get bored.

content:
Posted: October 1, 2015
												Game goes fine until a mid-game "change" (trying to avoid spoiler). After this, the game becomes nigh unplayable IMO. The simplest of missions will involve you taking down 30+ ships.....with your 4. They do come in waves somewhat, but thats little consolation. Your reward for this slaughter, should you succeed? Not enough enough resources to rebuild a single huge ship (the largest hanger size you can field). The only other game i can think of that i've played where i hit a "wall" akin to this was Diablo 3 in torment. Maybe some hardcore people enjoy beating their head painfully against walls like this, but unless you consider yourself one of them. Dont waste the initial 20-30 hours getting to that point. Save yourself the effort and just go bash your head on the nearest doorframe.

You go to a system, see how much the local two factions feel about you, see what you can buy from the faction that likes you, chill out by a friendly mining station to get resources, see what missions you can do that don't♥♥♥♥♥♥off the faction that doesn't like you, go bribe the other faction so you can buy their stuff, find some way of getting more crew to replace the ones you lost bribing your new friends, and then when the system is done, either bribe some more to unlock the warp gates, or shoot your friends in the back.  Story missions are massive spikes in difficulty requiring a lot of leveling from you.  They didn't make a massive randomly generated galaxy for the fun of it, as you will be wandering around picking fights and strip-mining it to get the xp and tech needed.  Just not for me as I don't have the time.

content:
Posted: November 10, 2013
												I expected more of a strategy game, but the bulk of the gameplay in Space Pirates and Zombies (SPAZ) is about twitchy 2D space combat.I struggled to master the controls. I would have preferred a basic twin-stick control system, like Robotron. Instead, SPAZ features an awkward combination of using the keyboard for thrusters, and the mouse for direction and aim. The result is a game that looks like hockey pucks on an ice rink flying around, shooting wildly at each other. It's really unpleasant to play.I've played the tutorial mission through twice now, and each time I have come away wondering why I would want to continue. The gameplay is poor, and the various elements of SPAZ don't come together to make a pleasing whole. I'm underwhelmed, and happy to set this aside.

content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												The worst game I ever played in my entire life. Everything is boring, nothing gets you entertained.SPAZ is a space "shooter" game and when you are used to control fast engines, in this game it's freaking slow and for the best part of the game, you're shooting lasers, because missiles are mainstream.You mostly take 10 minutes to kill a piece of sh*t with those lasers and again, when you think you're almost having fun, the ennemies are flying 20 000 km away but they won't leave the area, no, because you're having fun chasing them for nothing. In the end I got with a ship I couldn't destroy because he was escaping me anytime he's almost dying. And when he's out of my sight, he regenerates.The game has more than 100 areas to explore, all of them look the same and are infinite in length but empty of things.Each area has missions, pretty boring ones and repetitive. It also has a level system, 100 levels it seems, but totally useless because every ability you increase does no effect! It's only useful for new engine parts: lasers, shield, cloak, etc.The level can also tell you how hard an area can be. But you will always die more than 20 times before clearing one.There's plenty of ships to unlock, each ranged by class: small, medium, large, huge. You won't get something good before getting a huge ship, that means, in the end of the game when you have nothing else to do.However, mods can give a great visual but nobody gives a.. and only 2 mods are available: halloween and xmas. wow.I admit I played with a trainer but even with that it's a pain to play this horrible game.2.5/10

												This topdown shmup isn't just a arcade top down shmup like astroids. The game has rpg elements where you have to do missions and upgrade your fleet. In Mount&Blade style you have a fleet just control one ship in battles. It's a nice twist on the genre. But the problem is that the shmup gameplay is boring. The controls are bad. content:
Posted: June 29, 2013
												Before you ask, no, i dont have a steam copy, my copy of this game is actually non-steam (humble bundle, look it up), but this is a really cool ship combat game that i suck at.  Despite the cheesy title, this game is actually a really fun game all in all, mixing all sorts of things into the game.Storyline in a nutshell: New element, Rez, is discovered. This one government, the UTA, uses this element to make warp gates that can let ships travel to different solar systems. However, they're total warp-gate nazis and the civilians dont like it, so they get their own ships and start fighting UTA (peaceful civilians... who said that?) ships all over.Just a little background knowledge.Now, what you do is use these ships to take a side on factions... don't worry, whatever you do will only affect faction relations in the system you're in, which means you can go take down a huge UTA convoy, go to a different system, and poof! Aside from that system, nobody gives a crap! Very fun gameplay, and when it comes to taking sides, its always open for change. However, you will start at different levels of relations with factions per system, and... whatever. Just play the game already.

content:
Posted: February 12, 2014
												If you are offended by foul language, steer clear. It isn't just enemy pilots about to die; it isn't just in dialogs with lowlifes; it is in the ambient sound for the game itself (presumably intercom chatter aboard your own vessel). Totally unnecessary, and adds no value to the game.Now, after turning the noise completely off, and ignoring the dialogs (which you can probably get away with, since the in-game indicators tell you what you need to do next), you can get around that objection, so what is left?A lot of grinding. I don't mind grinding, generally, but I appreciate some sort of appreciable reward for grinding. Admittedly, I didn't go far in the game, but the whole time I felt behind.Regrets that I can't give a positive comment. Building and maintaining a small space task force is right up my alley, so I thought it would be great. It isn't.

content:
Posted: August 14, 2016
												"There is potential here, the ship customization is nice.But the game also feels very grindy. Some missions are fun, others just feel like BS-Also the control sceme is somewhat awkward."The bit above was my original review, i wrote it about 3 or so hours into the game.Now, having finished it after about 45hrs of playtime (that's a single playthrough, so if the game can keep you engaged, there is very good playtime value in it... Most of it was repetive/grind-ish missions however), i am somewhat torn. In the long run it was better,  than my first impression. Certainly not terrible. However, was it good enough, to change my vote? I don't think so. On a more refined scale, i would have voted differently - a 6 out of 10 perhaps. But with only "Yay" or "Nay" as possible votes, i'll stick to my initial negative vote.After all, after wrtitng that original bit, i stopped playing for a few days. Might havenever returned, but was really-really bored, so took it up again.A few nice extras came up, but my two main complaints - grind and awkward controls - remained in place.The story was ok for a open world-ish combat game, where no one really cares about story anyway. Predictable and very cliche, but enough to keep you moving from chapter to chapter. Actaully, when changing chapters there were a few interesting changes in the mechanics. Late game even had something a kin to a basic strategic layer, with defense chokepoints and ressource management - very-very-very basic, but nevertheless, an interesting change of pace.However, it did not do away with the grindy-ness. Rather the need for ressources increased. To progress the story i had to do the same missions over and over again (same objectives, slightly different maps). In the end i was just cherry-picking the missions, that i could do the fastest (cloak, destroy the target, get out).I had unlocked all the ships, all the modules about half way through the game. Picked my favorites rather quickly too. Most new unlocks i only tried for a short while (one or two fights), found them inferior, to what i already had and never used them again.Now, i am willing to believe, that there is some bit of personal prefference involved - other player might select other ships at some point. However, there is also somewhat poor balance - some ships of the same class, are clearly and stricktly superior to others - more health, more equipment slots.Bounty hunter designs in particular seem very strong - perhaps a sort of power creep in the development process.My main complaint remains the control scheme, even after 45 hours of gameplay i still wasn't fully used to it. I can't even rightly describe it - it's just not intuitive. Basically the strafe controls are pivoted on the ship, rather than on the screen. And since the ship can be spinning all willy-nilly, depending on where you aim your mouse (which is where your target is, so you can't just say "screw it" and steer with the mouse), the direction of strafing is kinda flipping around, so sometimes ushing left, will make you move left, while other times you push left, yet go right. That made strafing completely unviable for me.

content:
Posted: July 23, 2016
												A conceptually good game that ultimately suffers from being very grindy and surprisingly difficult.  The grindy-ness is kind of just the nature of the game and if you can deal with the controls and feel immersed in the universe and enjoy the combat, you probably won't care.  Most games are repetitve after all.  But I found the universe to not be quite as interesting as advertised and the rpg-like elemnts of the game to be not bad per-se, but not really compelling or interesting either.The difficulty is at least to some degree, a by-product ofthe awkward controls.  This game needs controller support, it begs to have twin-stick controls.  Its just too hard otherwise it would be a fine little game.  A lot of people apparently adapted to the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ controls but I just couldn't as a long time Geometry Wars type player I just can't get the hang of the combat........and thats the entire game so yea.  Its slightly unfair of me to knock the game because I suck at it......but how much foresight and budget would it really have taken for them to include controller support?  Ring Runner Flight of the Sages manages it at a similar price-point and would be the game I would recommend instead.

content:
Posted: September 29, 2016
												I really wanted to like this game and there's quite a few things that are good about it, but it's just not nearly enough to recommend this...What is SPAZ?This game puts you in a more or less randomly generated 2D galaxy. You can set the amount of star systems, the difficulty, the tech advancements and randomize the tech tree. That's pretty much it. I've played a game with 300 systems and started one with 150. I honestly don't see the difference, which already brings me to the biggest issue I have with it:This game is utterly and truly boring. You are going to do the same thing over and over and over and over again. That is: Fly to a subsystem, complete missions to raise your standing with 1 of the 2 factions, which of course hate each other, in order to gain resources you need to (re)build ships, gather upgrade points and buy new modules like better shields, etc.There is a main mission to follow, but honestly after 10 hours of gameplay I've not been able to progress this very much, since every main mission is multiple sub systems apart. Now, you've got to understand that these subsystems have a level requirement attached to it, which means you need to break a blockade to access a new subystem. That in turn means grinding out levels to get more upgrades and fighting against superior foes either technologically speaking or just sheer numbers. The next problem with this is that you only get new and better ships by destroying these same ships multiple times first to get the blueprints. In my first playthrough I just didn't get any good ships that would even survive against the enemy for a few seconds most of the time. It doesn't help that most damage is unavoidable and your ai ships are dumb as ♥♥♥♥.In the end this means ginding, grinding, grinding...and that's not what I was looking for in a space exploration and combat game. Not to mention that after 10 hours there are still no zombies, so I can't even comment on how the gameplay changes after you reach that stage, but since I was finally able to complete another main mission, only to realize I need to grind another TEN levels to even GET to the next mission area I said "♥♥♥♥ you", as this is a bottomless pit. Even with just 150 subystems you're going to be doing this for 100 hours I feel. Not worth it, especially since the gameplay does not change at all throughout the whole game. The only difference is that you get bigger ships that move slower, but the main combat system and weapons stay the same. Pretty disappointed in this one. :/

content:
Posted: January 14
Product received for free
												Oh, look! A game set in space where you to read tons of witty text to learn how to build ships! And it got "Zombie" in the title! Not boring or ripetitive at all! SO indie and original! I really do not like this game. Often compared to Star Control, it has neither the charm nor the entertainment of the game. It tries to imitate an old game style that died for a reason; it's not very good. The game starts off promising, shoots itself in the foot. The game is Repetitive, with a capital R, with such abysmal lack of content I don't understand how it got released in like so. You get maybe a handful of ships to play with, and the majority of them you will never use. At no point in time through playing the game did I ever concern myself with resources, as there was never any need. If you play well you're given everything you ever need. The missions feel tedious and the grinding for blueprints is aggravating, not to mention the restrictive modular system it presents. Why make such an amazing modular setup, then take it away, forcing specific pieces on the ship designs? So instead of getting a massive fleet of awesome variety, you get... cookie cutter setups. It makes the whole system feel a waste.Perhaps I am too hard on the game. It gave me 2 hours of entertainment! But afterwards, it felt so old, so repetitive

Posted: November 26, 2012
												Top down space shooter with an addictive progression system. It feels like a 2D Freelancer flying around upgrading ships, blowing up pirates, civilians, zombies, police cruisers all the while upgrading your little band of mercenary ships makes for an absolutely fantastic time. The open ended nature of the game gives the player freedom to go where they like while the narrative gives a general direction on where to go next. Combat is fluid and each ship handles a little differently as a space game should. All this made by two people. Weapon and ship upgrades keep the player going for 'just a bit longer' into the wee hours of next week.Get it, play it, love it.

Posted: August 18, 2011
												This is really a good game.  And, it's only about 150MB to install.  It's a space exploration, resource gathering, space combat strategy.  I'm not much into RTS games, and this game doesn't play like one.  You have a mother ship, and then control individual ships in your fleet.  You can switch between any ship, and also set up AI for those ships you aren't currently controlling.  The galaxy is proceedurally generated when you start a new game, and you can control the number of star systems up to about 300 total.  Each star system has a level requirement before you can visit it, and you have to deal with the ships guarding the Jump Gates (bribe or destroy) before you can move freely between systems you have access to.Really, try the demo.  The tutorial is for the first system but seems to open up after about the 1st or 2nd mission you take.  This 2 person dev team deserve your money.
