Posted: February 12, 2012
												If you remember Escape Velocity and miss the good-ol-days of 2-D space battles, then SPAZ may satisfy your hunger.  The very beginning is hard, but the difficulty smoothes out over time and you can expect to be butchering the enemy towards end-game (on the non-insane difficulty settings).  A surprisingly well-polished game for only a two-man indie crew. The only real gripe I have  the lackluster AI which seems to only have one rule set: KAMEKAZI! and the lack of mission types.  Expect to be going from point A to point B and killing everything or collecting X amount of things.Overall an enjoyable game with a good amount of customization.

Posted: January 28, 2012
												This is a game of a style (had I the time and the talent) I have always wanted to make.  It's a very pleasant combination of genres.  The closest game I can think of that would be similar is Starscape.Shoot asteroids for resources, kill ships for xp and crew.  Defeat a new type of ship and you get their blueprint.  Get enough of that blueprint and you can build that ship.  Blast your way through blockades, or trade and bribe your way past.The loadout interface is surprisingly easy.  It's fun experimenting with different components and weapons on different hardpoints of different hulls.  Do I add a way stronger blaster and hope I don't run out of reactor power in the middle of a fight?  Do I prefer speed or maneuverability?  Cloak or shields?  Bombs, drones, torpedoes or missiles?  Tracking turrets or forward-facing sheer oomph?The middle-end of the game gets a bit grindy, but the collector/completionist in me still has plenty to do.  The developers are cool and keep adding stuff!

Posted: December 21, 2012
												A neat little space arena that brings back distant memories of Subspace. Probably worth buying  only because there's virtually no competition in the genre. It can be frustrating not being able to zoom out more when you're being shot off-screen, and the drawn graphics such as pilot avatars and Civ relations come off as very sloppy when I think they were going for charming. The main story gets monotonous because you don't choose to grind if you want better tech, you HAVE to grind for better tech. But the gameplay does get a breath of fresh air when you start to battle zombies and build up your uninfected armada. But the real draw is the core gameplay of top-down, space dog-fighting. Taking out an enemy ship on your own is very rewarding and subsequently, being killed will have you cursing under your breath. If you're a masochist like me, there's worse ways to spend three bucks. Plus, it's easy to tell that the devs could do a lot with a little more funding.

Posted: August 16, 2011
												After following the development of this game for a while I am pleased to say that the wait was worth it. As with games like Terraria and Super Meat Boy, do not be fooled by the simplified graphics as it more than makes up for them in playability and addictive content.The game universe is HUGE, hundreds of star systems each with multiple planets for you to explore. Each planet within a system offers missions or events for you to encounter. As you complete one mission another is generated as the universe evolves with every action you take.On release there are over 30 ships for you to obtain and dozens of technologies to research. In order to advance the available technologies or ship designs you will have to blast your way through the galaxy and salvage the blueprints and data you need.The only criticism I would make is that there is no multiplay feature but the developers are continually adding content to the game and hopefully they integrate multiplayer mode(s) in the future.

Posted: April 29, 2014
												An interesting 2D shooter with RPG and strategy elements. There is not as much variety to weaponry as I would like, however this can be rectified with 3rd party mods. The moment to moment gameplay usually consists of blasting enemy ships to pieces, then swooping over their dropped black boxes to pick up blueprints to build more ships, and resources to level up and purchase new weapons.The Zombies in the game do provide an interesting mix up to the standard space combat, manifesting as infected ships that can shoot zombies at you. The UI could be more intuitive, some interesting options are buried in drop down menus that may not be obvious to most players; the ability for turrets to autofire is extremely useful, but is hidden in a drop down box and thus went unnoticed for a very long time. Graphics wise, the game will win no awards; however the textures and effects are servicable and lean more toward the humorous side of things. The tone of the game is not overly serious, this is quite succintly conveyed by the cheesy dialogue. The story is enitrely forgettable, as is the back story. It all reads like some terrible work of fan fiction; I understand that such a small dev team is unlikely to be able to afford a decent script writer, but attempts could have been made to hone their writing skills through free online courses.The game is fairly customizable upon start up, and runs well even on a back - up Intel GPU on a laptop. Overall, given the price, I would highly recommend this game to anyone interested in space games or 2D shooters. It is obvious that a lot of love went into the production of this game, you are even greeted with a thank - you from the developer every time you start the game up. I look forward to the impending sequel, and wish that there were more games of this type floating about on Steam.

												The game is hands down one of the best indie games I have played in the past few years, easily in my top 5 indie games when you consider it's "fun factor". The graphics are very pleasing especially for a cartoon look. The sound fit's the game well as does the artwork. SPAZ has several difficulty settings ranging from "casual just play for fun and never lose" to "please just kill me now". On it's most difficult setting even the most experienced gamers will be tested. The galaxy can be created relatively small (still very large offering many hours of gameplay) to massive offering literally hundreds of hours of play time. The map is also randomly generated so replay value is high. Bounty Hunters (free DLC) adds a fourth faction to interact with adding new ways to explore or destroy star systems!All in all a highly suggested purchase that will offer something to all gamers, casual and hardcore alike.

Posted: September 23, 2014
												Score BasedChallenge - A- Game is intuitive, presents a reasonable difficulty progression, and a excellent learning curve Starting Tutorial is fun and engaging presenting the necessary information without being boring Minus a few points for content that wile interesting, where also tedious and overly time consuming.Game Quality - C Game is very well designed and provides a fresh and unique feel that sets it apart from other similar games. Content is fun and varied, supports a large number of play styles and tactics, all retaining use throughout the game Biggest hit was for low Replayability.  after beating the game i just didn’t feel any need to keep playing.Refinement – A Played the entire game, start to finish, and never once crashed or encountered a noticeable bug  Balance and effectiveness of ship types and equipment scale well with difficulty (altho some ships never get used due to late availability in the game, making some of the contents use questionable) Developers seam to take an active role in the games player community (very impressive for only a handfull of people)Presentation – B Not a graphics intensive game, however what is included is well themed and well implemented User interface is intuitive and easy to use Kind of hokey in an odd sort of way.  Story line is a little weak, however still fun and interesting enough Hype was dead on.  This game is exactly what it looks like, exactly as advertised, and well worth the play time.Additional Content – B+ Game supports all manner of Mods and additional content Developers have released a small number of fun holiday themed mods for community use Modding utilities have also been released to general community, they are complete and effective they do however require some investment in time, energy, and learning to use correctly  Relatively active player community, including a functional wiki, and several active modding forums.Fun – C+ Surprisingly Immersive, despite its rather primitive look, engaging and enjoyable Intensive enough to keep the players attention, however some aspects did become tedious and frustrating. Wile not in my top 10.  It defiantly has several core quality’s that make it a 'Must Have' for any game collection  Total Grade – Solid 'B+'this is a very good game.  A solid experience all the more impressive due to volume of content, and the relatively small development staff.  At the time of writing, this the game is priced at $9.99 and it is worth every penny.  Will likely get SPAZ 2 when it comes out.

Posted: September 23, 2014
												I played the SPAZ demo, and I liked it, though maybe not enough to buy the full game if it hadn't been on sale, at a reduced price. Good thing for me that it was, because now I'm 20+ hours into it and I'm loving it!I'm finding a surprising amount of depth and customization in this little indie game. At first, I was a wee bit turned off by the arcadish, Asteroids-like combat. Eventually, I learned that I could build a mid-size command ship with an automated turret armed with a cannon or beam weapon, with me manually controlling the ship's guided missile launchers. With this, I could return fire on an enemy ship while circle-strafing around it, keeping my weakened shields/armor facing away from it. Meanwhile, I could have a couple of small, AI-controlled teammate ships to pepper the enemy from its flanks.So, I grew to love the combat! Especially as I got even deeper into the tech research/acquisition and ship customization/optimization. (Now I'm starting to explore the use of a carrier as my command ship, which launches squadrons of fighter-drones into battle.) The game has become, for me, less arcadish and dependent on hand-eye coordination/reflexes, and more tactical and dependent on thinking/planning.And not just tactical, but strategic as well. Strategic in battle, when figuring out how best to deal with enemy fleets and space stations, but also strategic when plotting my overall route across the star map and  my individual routes within the separate star systems; and also when dealing with the game's three factions (the military-police, the rebel colonists, and the anarchistic bounty hunters).Yes, a great little indie game, especially for a two-man design/developer team. I've already placed the upcoming sequel for SPAZ on my wishlist!

Posted: August 5, 2015
												Goofy name, amazing game.Keeping it short this game is amazing if you're into customizable ships, strategic real time combat, and an open world to travel and explore as you see fit but with a storyline and a specific overall goal. In many ways it's kind of like a real time Space Rangers. And it has a ton of replayability. There are a wide array of skills that dramatically increase the effectiveness of certain mutually exclusive parts (like a shield or a cloaking device) and also allow access to interesting and unique versions of said item. So for instance you might play through one game using cloaks and missiles, whereas another game you might not use a cloak or a shield and instead rely on armor, hull and improving the capability of your crew to repair damage while you're taking it. Options, options, options. All quite well balanced and viable, even if some are 'more viable' than others.

Posted: January 3, 2012
												Now here's a game that quietly passed underneath my radar. I thought it was going to be too strategy based for my liking, but there isn't a whole lot of strategy to it. It's more like a casual space exploration game that integrates action based combat. As you progress, the battles can get pretty intense, but there's no pressure because you don't lose the game if you lose a battle allowing you to experiment and move at your own pace. Usually you just have to reassess your ship configurations if you get into a situation you can't handle.There is a slight learning curve, but nothing overwhelming. The galaxy is very large providing hundreds of hours of potential play and the game always seems to throw you a new challenge as you advance, so it doesn't get repetitively boring. There's plenty to do between the main story mission, side missions, and the variety of faction objectives in each system. Hands down, SPAZ is a game that should be in your collection.

Posted: October 17, 2015
												SPAZ is a great space-combat game. I haven't played a space game this fun since Escape Velocity: Nova. If the 2D space genre at all interests you, you need to buy it, now. Fans of this game should also take a look at Drox Operative, which takes a more Diablo-esque stance to space combat, though I find that controls in that game to be less fun.This game, though fun, lacks a fair amount of depth. it has it's problems, and I shall list some of those out here. Make no mistake, my overall rating for this game would still be an 8/10.First of all, alt+tabbing is a bit of a pain. You need an active window to tab into otherwise it won't work.The intro movies, though short, are not skippable.Skipping the tutorial leaves you at a bit of a disadvantage level wise.I cannot figure out enemy aggro. Sometimes, they choose to target exclusively my own ships despite other enemy ships attacking them.On a mission to kill enemy scouts, if the scouts are friendly, it is impossible because my own ships will not target them.I cannot select enemy ships to be targeted from the tactical menu. Targeting specific enemy ships can be a pain sometimes and this would help immensely.Enemy ships will often only attack my escorts. And my escorts will fly way off to attack enemy ships. This has led to all my rez being depleted while I just sit there and do nothing.More AI options are needed. Even defensive AI is way too aggressive. An AI option where friendly ships never leave the screen would be nice.Better yet, formations would be a welcome addition to the game. Even just one basic formation would be extremely helpful in keeping my fleet in line.Friendly AI ships get♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off way too easily.There aren't enough missions to weaken the enemy faction in a given system. This forces me to either attack a level 3 space station, or make peace with the enemy at the expense of my ally.As a final sidenote, I love the radio chatter that goes on. You should allow people to upload their own chatter for inclusion into the game somehow.

												10/10 Very addictive game.  I played about 1 hour of this game 18 months ago then came back and started a new game 2 weeks ago.  It took me 80 hrs to complete a new game.  The addictive part of the game is chasing the next upgrade, blueprint or skill levelup.   I recomend game saving alot early-mid game.  The game was very challenging till, Hammerhead ship dropped toward the middle of chapter 3. The game became super easy after getting max level cannons and Mammath during chapter 4.  Mammath is OP with triple mount Partical Cannons, double mount Mass Drivers, and Battle Station.   This game reminds me of a 100x more advanced version of Asteroids, that I played hundreds of times in the mid-80s at the YMCA.  The game has a good story and great 2d graphics.  Another similarly enjoyable game to try is Reassembly.

												Now of course there is room for improvement but it does so many things well. The battles are fun, intense and usually pretty challenging. The management elements have depth and require thought and skill but aren't as daunting as you would expect. Un-lockable hull types with the ability to customize those hulls, weapons, shields and more. A very pretty game graphically, especially for an indie game with a 2 man development team. I've spent time just watching the A.I. battles that play in the background on the main menu screen. Now the ship controls can feel a little odd at first but once you get used to them they make sense. In short, if you have any interest in space battles and fun sci fi stories you have to own this game. I love it and have bought multiple copies for my friends. Good luck and I hope you enjoy it as much as I do.

Pretty scary.  10/10

Posted: August 3, 2015
												Space Pirates and Zombies appears at first glance nothing more than a retro style, 2d space shooter. But after playing it a lot, multiple playthroughs and challenges, it has a ton of depth lying beneath it's 2d surface.You start as the leader of a small band of merchant pirates yourself seeking your fortune by collecting mineral deposits call rez. There are rumors of enormous stockpiles or rez near the core worlds so you set off to seek them out. Along the way you encounter zombies and eventually take on the gargantuan task of ridding the galaxy of them.The first thing you do is set your world settings. There's multiple difficulty levels, 5 or 6 in total so you can vary your experience immensely, as well as settings for galaxy size, pirate density and tech distribution. You can create a unique experience for every game.Once you are playing the game has three main areas. First is the galaxy and system maps. You travel to different systems and you can select various missions in each one to level up your crew, buy or steal tech and collect rez and ship designs. The systems all have different levels so you have to decide what you can potentially accomplish.The next big part is your ship loadout screens, tech and hangar. In the tech screen you spend data (experience) that you have gather to level up various ship systems like beam weapons or shields. Each level increases the effectiveness of your systems and some levels are a prerequisite to advanced tech. Like you need level three beams to deploy particle beams or something. Then in the hanger you choose which hulls to use and what systems to put on them. You start with three hangars at the beginning of the game and get four by the end with larger capacity for larger hulls.The final major area is actually flying your ships on the planet or area of interest screens. They aren't always combat screens, some missions you might gather rez for example. But while on these screens you can switch control between all your ships as well as issuing orders to the other ships to do certain things like rendezvous over here or attack this target. Sometimes pirates show up, sometimes zombies, all depends on the mission. I found there to be a good variety of events and missions.The actual combat is extremely interesting if you make it challenging enough. Because there are so many types of ships and systems the way you fight can be varied. You might make a fast missile boat ship and whittle targets down while keeping out of their gun range. Or you might make a stealth capable ship, get in close and crush em with high powered beam cutters. Or maybe you want to use rotating turrets to track fast moving targets. It's up to you, there's no wrong way to do it, and a lot of times you have to adjust on the fly based on the tech available.Hull designs are obtained by killing enemy ships of that hull. Sometimes one ship is enough but most need 3 or 4 blueprint pieces. Tech for subsystems like weapons, engines and all that is obtained from planets either by trading with them or blowing up their bases and taking it. There's also specialist crew members who give you distinct bonuses like +10% cannon damage. So that has to be taken into account as well.In all there's a ton of ways to customize your game and your ships and it's very fun. I enjoyed leveling in this game immensely. The only downside is the hardest difficulties are REALLY hard and you end up basically grinding resources in low level areas to advance. But hard should be hard so I commend the devs for doing that. I guess you could fly smarter, not harder, if you're really good and get by with less.Finally there's challenges too via a little space arena the pirates run. It's a good way to make money and there's some achievements with it. Some are very hard.This game simply rocks and you have to try it.

Posted: August 5, 2015
												Goofy name, amazing game.Keeping it short this game is amazing if you're into customizable ships, strategic real time combat, and an open world to travel and explore as you see fit but with a storyline and a specific overall goal. In many ways it's kind of like a real time Space Rangers. And it has a ton of replayability. There are a wide array of skills that dramatically increase the effectiveness of certain mutually exclusive parts (like a shield or a cloaking device) and also allow access to interesting and unique versions of said item. So for instance you might play through one game using cloaks and missiles, whereas another game you might not use a cloak or a shield and instead rely on armor, hull and improving the capability of your crew to repair damage while you're taking it. Options, options, options. All quite well balanced and viable, even if some are 'more viable' than others.

Posted: July 2, 2015
												I had a ton of fun with this indie gem.  The game is easy to pick up, but delivers on strategic challenge later on.   The battles are usually fast-paced and enjoyable, with many different valid strategic approaches.  Except for a few technologies that go obsolete, all the equipment you find can be used right up through the endgame, because you can equip small AI-controlled helper ships to help you on missions. I did find that the game was too easy, but I could have raised the difficulty.  Also, sometimes the enemy AI will use a fast ship and simply fly away from you, which it can do indefinitely, making it impossible to complete a mission.  This means that you may have to repeat a few missions for no other reason than that.  If you want a multiplayer experience, hold off and buy SPAZ 2, as this one unfortunately lacks that feature.

Posted: April 22, 2015
												First my profile: 44y, born in France and living in Canada, I am a casual player for the last 25y ( and an adict the first 5y) so I played tons of games from various genre, mostly on PC.I highly recommend this game, mostly because it's fun.I have rarely completed game twice but as I foundly remembered the game, I tried it once more and realized there was a new update that added bounty hunters and realized they re-balanced the game, which likely explain some of the earlier bad score.I somewhat forgot some of the game mechanic but it all came back and I can  say doing it all over again was pure joy.The game has a good mix of strategy, story telling, action and progression.I love to pilote a small fleet and the many options to go about the difficult missions. Some complain the difficulty curve is too high, especially in mid-game, but I would say that it is a welcome challenge as the AI is quite weak and they are many ways to exploit it. There is a bit of grinding but I kind of like it myself being a bit perfectionist with games and liking to explore all there is to see and find secrets so be warned.It's a two man game and I find that inspiring, those guys have talents and I can't wait to put my hand on SPAZ 2 when it comes out.THe graphics are not for everyone but I personally like it and 2D worked for piloting the ships.The music was repetitive but pleasant and I did not get tired of it. I find music can play a bit part of your long term memory of the joy of playing a game and this one is still lingering in my subconcient.Overall a 9/10 for me.

Posted: August 30, 2012
												SPAZ... oh SPAZ, how i love you... Space Pirates and Zombies is a game that deserve... Nein! It NEEDS more attention. Its a great game made by 2 great dudes. They are working (slowly) on SPAZ 2.I really have nothing, nothing bad to say about this game. The trailer they got is a great way to show off how to game works, what you see is what you get. So if you like what you see then buy it, its a great game.Here's what i think of the game. The game is a fun little game where you fly around with a small fleet of spaceship. You have a mothership that you can't control and it rebuilds and refit all your spaceships to your need. You start of with only one ship, and gain the ability to use other ships by destroying that type of ship, once destroyed the ship drops a blueprint, collect them to unlock the ship for yourself. The larger the ship, the more blueprints you need. So a small fighter might only need two pieces of that blueprint, destroy 2, collect the blueprint and the fighter is yours. While cruisers and battleships might need up to 8 blueprints, and they usally have alot more health and are harder to kill.You also get the ability to refit your ships with weapons you want to use. Each ship has its own number of hardpoints, you can mix and match and put whatever you want on your ship. Want to fire kinetic rounds? sure. Lasers? Why not. Plasma balls? It's your ship, your rules.Now this might be a minor spoiler but they got it in the title of the game so... Story goes that you are a space pirate, each solar system is cut off from each other so what you do in one system won't carry over to the next. To get to another system (a higher leveled one with more advanced ships) you'll have to fight through a UTA Blockade, they block access to the warpgates you need access to procedd in the game, either destroy them all or bribe them to give you access. Each system has 2 factions. The UTA (Military, always blocks the warpgates with blockades). And the Civvies, they control mining and science operations in deep space and usally let you use their facility freely (So you can mine resource, et.c.). You will randomly get a faction rating in each starsystem, sometimes they love you from the start, sometimes they hate you. You'll never know. Pick your side, start blasting ships from the oppossite side and soon you'll make some great friends in that starsystem.Later on in the game Zombie ships start to appear, and near the end of the game they will be your main enemy. The UTA and Civvies notice the major zombie problem and team up together with you to reclaim the galaxy from the zombies. Zombie ships are unique ships that you can not unlock. They consist of two type of ships, fighting type ships that look like infected normal ships. They will engage anyone mindlessly. And then we got the breed type ships that look like human bodyparts of some sort. They infect ships without shields, if your ship gets infected you have little time to react, either self destruct your ship so the zombies can't gain control of it and use it against you... or make the hard choice and vent the ship of all crew except the captain, so the infection can't spread. It's a hard job late game, but someone has to purge the galaxy from the zombies.There is also a fourth faction that was released freely with the game. And they are the Bounty Hunters. There ships are unique with specific traits and are also very, very over powered. If you go around in a starsystem they "control" and wreck havoc, you will start to lose respect with them. Lose to much of it and they will warp in when you least want it (in a difficult fight with another faction) and try to blow you out of the space, for the most part they succedd with this. One of the hardest achivements ingame want's you to destroy their space station in the hardest type of starsystem.So will you use standard weapons like lasers, kinetic rounds or plasma to destroy your enemies? or will you go for missiles and torpedos instead? Why not use EMP weapons and energy drainers to drain all energy from your enemy ships so they can't fire their weapons or escape? Nukes? Sure, SPAZ has them. Drones for carriers, that too. There is alot to do with this game, and it gave me alot of hours of fun.The only three really bad parts about this game are:Interface dosen't look very professional.The story isen't that good, it had one somewhat good plot twist in it tho.The last "part" of the game, the "purge" all galaxy of zombie threat's is a repeative and somewhat boring job to do. Everything before that is fun tho.

												does exactly what a space strategy rpg should... allow you to pilot awesome ships into combat, apply varied tactical maneuvers that count. After replaying the game twice, there are some minor flaws but I see how everything went right: The devs focused on EXCATLY what was important, and I enjoyed it immensely.pros:- its fun. command your fleet against a solid AI, where you'll need micro tactics, planning and skill.- rewarding, make the right moves and you won't need to grind.- challenging, difficulty grows with you- requires strategy for star systems- good learning curve at the startcons:- learning curve can be tricky: if you pick the wrong things or try to do something stupid like bashing through a super high level defense... duh you die, and pay for it harshly.- make the wrong choice to leap forward on the story and again you pay for it as costs rise.- some inbalance in weapons and ships. Posted: February 21, 2015
												I used to love a game called Escape Velocity which is now more or less defunct, but SPAZ has brought back that classic feel and gameplay style of 2D arcade shooter + galaxy exploration in a great way.Really nice art direction and a couple of extra additions in gameplay mechanic to the old EV style.I'm not sure what exactly I would change but it would be nice if the ship and abilities upgrade systems were a little different. Posted: August 18, 2011
												This is really a good game.  And, it's only about 150MB to install.  It's a space exploration, resource gathering, space combat strategy.  I'm not much into RTS games, and this game doesn't play like one.  You have a mother ship, and then control individual ships in your fleet.  You can switch between any ship, and also set up AI for those ships you aren't currently controlling.  The galaxy is proceedurally generated when you start a new game, and you can control the number of star systems up to about 300 total.  Each star system has a level requirement before you can visit it, and you have to deal with the ships guarding the Jump Gates (bribe or destroy) before you can move freely between systems you have access to.Really, try the demo.  The tutorial is for the first system but seems to open up after about the 1st or 2nd mission you take.  This 2 person dev team deserve your money.

Posted: June 30, 2014
												Space Pirates and Zombies. Remember Starscape? This feels a lot like a very well-done and much-improved sequal to Starscape. You fly around different space zones collecting resources that you use to upgrade your mothership, unlock new fighter chassis and build fighters.So how does it hold up? I think very well. A word about control: Don't bother without a mouse. Personally, there are very few games that require both mouse and keyboard that I will play with a laptop touchpad. This is not one of them. It's a very twitchy game, and the awkwardness of having one hand under my other wrist and having to click both buttons with my thumb is just too clumsy for me.The graphics are fun. The fighter/shuttle designs are different enough to be interesting, and the effects are flashy enough to be from a JJ Abrams movie.They make a half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥attempt at realistic physics, which is not really the rule with space games. That is to say: inertia is a thing, but not the infinite thing that it really ought to be. If you cut your engines, you will keep going but eventually stop. Is it always impressive when a game DOES have realistic physics? Yup. Is it always fun? Nope.  To that point, SPAZ makes it fun.

												Played this game for about a week now. I find it enjoyable and challenging even though it gets a little repetitive after while. You are always a step behind in ships but you can upgrade your weapons, shields, armor, etc before the enemy. Early ships are given to you once you beat it in battle. The smaller ships are done in one battle. As you get to larger ships you have to beat the same type ship from twice to, well I am at level 54 and I have beaten some ships 4 times already and I am only at 80% reverse engineered for that ship type.  You always have ways of getting Spaz (money) to spend, sometimes quickly other times you have to work for it. As you move up to higher levels the battles get more intense and are fun. Right now I have three ships on Level 54 the enemy might start with 4 or 5 then as you beat them they warp in a few more with one a little bigger than what you have sometimes. In between battles you can upgrade and find Spaz. The universe is quite larger with higher levels as you get to the inside systems. I just made it to the Zombie level and came back to upgrade more. I was no where near leveled up enough to stay there.I now have played the game twice. Very repetitive all the way through the game. Same thing in each system just as you level up you have more ships to beat, then the Bounty Hunters start showing up right after or during a battle making it that much harder to beat that level. Posted: April 16, 2013
												A rare gem. It makes a randomly (procedurally) generated universe for you to explore and battle around in. One of their last updates added bounty hunters, which change gameplay by a fair amount. You can play with or without the bounty hunters, though, as this game has a good selection of options when you are starting a new game. It's almost a sandbox game, but it's really more of a free-form RPG where you can go wherever you want whenever you want. It doesn't overwhelm you, though, because the difficulty for each solar system is clearly displayed.

The small team that created this did so "to make the kinds of games they used to make, but not anymore" and I can't think of a better way to put it. Like many 90s computer games, you'll start off totally lost once the extended tutorial ends, but that waywardness is the price you pay for the freedom SPaZ gives you.The price has gone down to less than five dollars before, so I'd pick it up then. Posted: September 22, 2014
												Highly addictive, and loads of fun. You collect resources, fight battles, gain levels, build bigger and better ships to take on bigger and better enemies and further unlock an impressively expansive galaxy. It's not a complicated game, but it can challenge you (and that's a good thing), which is where the addictive quality of SPAZ comes along. You never feel overpowered (not yet at least) because there are always more solar systems to explore with higher levels required to clear them, but you never feel underpowered either, because you get out as much effort as you put in to leveling up. You have to level up, and you have to explore, but level-grinding doesn't seem so bad because there are so many activities to do with a certain ammount of variety to them.  I also like the fact that you can play both sides of the coin when it comes to making allies or enemies out of the two factions of SPAZ's lore, and take on missions according to how your favor with either faction benefits you.I've sunk in about a dozen hours so far and have barely scratched the surface of the universe I'm exploring because of the game's exploratory rewards feeding the kleptomaniac in me. Highly reccomended. Oh, and did I mention that this game is loads of fun?

Posted: September 23, 2014
												I played the SPAZ demo, and I liked it, though maybe not enough to buy the full game if it hadn't been on sale, at a reduced price. Good thing for me that it was, because now I'm 20+ hours into it and I'm loving it!I'm finding a surprising amount of depth and customization in this little indie game. At first, I was a wee bit turned off by the arcadish, Asteroids-like combat. Eventually, I learned that I could build a mid-size command ship with an automated turret armed with a cannon or beam weapon, with me manually controlling the ship's guided missile launchers. With this, I could return fire on an enemy ship while circle-strafing around it, keeping my weakened shields/armor facing away from it. Meanwhile, I could have a couple of small, AI-controlled teammate ships to pepper the enemy from its flanks.So, I grew to love the combat! Especially as I got even deeper into the tech research/acquisition and ship customization/optimization. (Now I'm starting to explore the use of a carrier as my command ship, which launches squadrons of fighter-drones into battle.) The game has become, for me, less arcadish and dependent on hand-eye coordination/reflexes, and more tactical and dependent on thinking/planning.And not just tactical, but strategic as well. Strategic in battle, when figuring out how best to deal with enemy fleets and space stations, but also strategic when plotting my overall route across the star map and  my individual routes within the separate star systems; and also when dealing with the game's three factions (the military-police, the rebel colonists, and the anarchistic bounty hunters).Yes, a great little indie game, especially for a two-man design/developer team. I've already placed the upcoming sequel for SPAZ on my wishlist!

Posted: September 23, 2014
												Score BasedChallenge - A- Game is intuitive, presents a reasonable difficulty progression, and a excellent learning curve Starting Tutorial is fun and engaging presenting the necessary information without being boring Minus a few points for content that wile interesting, where also tedious and overly time consuming.Game Quality - C Game is very well designed and provides a fresh and unique feel that sets it apart from other similar games. Content is fun and varied, supports a large number of play styles and tactics, all retaining use throughout the game Biggest hit was for low Replayability.  after beating the game i just didn’t feel any need to keep playing.Refinement – A Played the entire game, start to finish, and never once crashed or encountered a noticeable bug  Balance and effectiveness of ship types and equipment scale well with difficulty (altho some ships never get used due to late availability in the game, making some of the contents use questionable) Developers seam to take an active role in the games player community (very impressive for only a handfull of people)Presentation – B Not a graphics intensive game, however what is included is well themed and well implemented User interface is intuitive and easy to use Kind of hokey in an odd sort of way.  Story line is a little weak, however still fun and interesting enough Hype was dead on.  This game is exactly what it looks like, exactly as advertised, and well worth the play time.Additional Content – B+ Game supports all manner of Mods and additional content Developers have released a small number of fun holiday themed mods for community use Modding utilities have also been released to general community, they are complete and effective they do however require some investment in time, energy, and learning to use correctly  Relatively active player community, including a functional wiki, and several active modding forums.Fun – C+ Surprisingly Immersive, despite its rather primitive look, engaging and enjoyable Intensive enough to keep the players attention, however some aspects did become tedious and frustrating. Wile not in my top 10.  It defiantly has several core quality’s that make it a 'Must Have' for any game collection  Total Grade – Solid 'B+'this is a very good game.  A solid experience all the more impressive due to volume of content, and the relatively small development staff.  At the time of writing, this the game is priced at $9.99 and it is worth every penny.  Will likely get SPAZ 2 when it comes out.

Posted: August 30, 2012
												SPAZ... oh SPAZ, how i love you... Space Pirates and Zombies is a game that deserve... Nein! It NEEDS more attention. Its a great game made by 2 great dudes. They are working (slowly) on SPAZ 2.I really have nothing, nothing bad to say about this game. The trailer they got is a great way to show off how to game works, what you see is what you get. So if you like what you see then buy it, its a great game.Here's what i think of the game. The game is a fun little game where you fly around with a small fleet of spaceship. You have a mothership that you can't control and it rebuilds and refit all your spaceships to your need. You start of with only one ship, and gain the ability to use other ships by destroying that type of ship, once destroyed the ship drops a blueprint, collect them to unlock the ship for yourself. The larger the ship, the more blueprints you need. So a small fighter might only need two pieces of that blueprint, destroy 2, collect the blueprint and the fighter is yours. While cruisers and battleships might need up to 8 blueprints, and they usally have alot more health and are harder to kill.You also get the ability to refit your ships with weapons you want to use. Each ship has its own number of hardpoints, you can mix and match and put whatever you want on your ship. Want to fire kinetic rounds? sure. Lasers? Why not. Plasma balls? It's your ship, your rules.Now this might be a minor spoiler but they got it in the title of the game so... Story goes that you are a space pirate, each solar system is cut off from each other so what you do in one system won't carry over to the next. To get to another system (a higher leveled one with more advanced ships) you'll have to fight through a UTA Blockade, they block access to the warpgates you need access to procedd in the game, either destroy them all or bribe them to give you access. Each system has 2 factions. The UTA (Military, always blocks the warpgates with blockades). And the Civvies, they control mining and science operations in deep space and usally let you use their facility freely (So you can mine resource, et.c.). You will randomly get a faction rating in each starsystem, sometimes they love you from the start, sometimes they hate you. You'll never know. Pick your side, start blasting ships from the oppossite side and soon you'll make some great friends in that starsystem.Later on in the game Zombie ships start to appear, and near the end of the game they will be your main enemy. The UTA and Civvies notice the major zombie problem and team up together with you to reclaim the galaxy from the zombies. Zombie ships are unique ships that you can not unlock. They consist of two type of ships, fighting type ships that look like infected normal ships. They will engage anyone mindlessly. And then we got the breed type ships that look like human bodyparts of some sort. They infect ships without shields, if your ship gets infected you have little time to react, either self destruct your ship so the zombies can't gain control of it and use it against you... or make the hard choice and vent the ship of all crew except the captain, so the infection can't spread. It's a hard job late game, but someone has to purge the galaxy from the zombies.There is also a fourth faction that was released freely with the game. And they are the Bounty Hunters. There ships are unique with specific traits and are also very, very over powered. If you go around in a starsystem they "control" and wreck havoc, you will start to lose respect with them. Lose to much of it and they will warp in when you least want it (in a difficult fight with another faction) and try to blow you out of the space, for the most part they succedd with this. One of the hardest achivements ingame want's you to destroy their space station in the hardest type of starsystem.So will you use standard weapons like lasers, kinetic rounds or plasma to destroy your enemies? or will you go for missiles and torpedos instead? Why not use EMP weapons and energy drainers to drain all energy from your enemy ships so they can't fire their weapons or escape? Nukes? Sure, SPAZ has them. Drones for carriers, that too. There is alot to do with this game, and it gave me alot of hours of fun.The only three really bad parts about this game are:Interface dosen't look very professional.The story isen't that good, it had one somewhat good plot twist in it tho.The last "part" of the game, the "purge" all galaxy of zombie threat's is a repeative and somewhat boring job to do. Everything before that is fun tho.

												SPAZ is an excellent combo of fun, weird, easy to play, strategy, and action! Just the right amounts each of simplicity and complexity. Posted: September 20, 2014
												I've played all 3 Escape Velocity games, if that is what these guys were trying to emulate they failed.This game is overly complicated from the beginning, it has a difficulty curve like a mountain and has combat that simply doesn't have a good feel to it, which is important as there isn't much more to this game.  There is a plot, some narration, but honestly the level of the dialouge and the amateur art designs for the charcacters caused me to ignore it after about 10 minutes.This is Diablo in space, you manuever around, try to damage opponents and mostly are just trying to click at the right times to line up shots against VERY agile opponents.   You also constantly have to keep track of how allies are doing, your ship is usually worse then your competitions and there are more of them then there are of your fleet (as opposed to most ARPGs where you have an advantage but you are facing a horde).  It is very easy to die but that's ok, because using your mined resources you can then use them to respawn yourself and your fleet.  But you can and will run out of resources, therefore making you not be able to respawn, at which point the game tells you to go get in a very very very crappy ship and start mining, but anyone with common sense will tell you to reload your save instead to save you the mindless grinding that would entail.This is grossly dissapointing because I feel there is a lot to this game, it generates a new galaxy for every game which would seem to have a huge amount of content but I couldn't get past the second star system and had great difficulty getting past the first (which was the tutorial).  Maybe this game was made for the nintendo hard crowd, or maybe I just suck, but I just don't have the time or patience anymore to deal with that.  Although after looking at the universal badge progress on this game, I can tell I'm not alone.Don't trust the metacritic score, although I will say there is something here but you have to be pretty dedicated/skilled to find it.

Posted: January 19, 2015
												This is probably the grindiest game I've ever played. It's not a bad game at all, but it has a few hours of fun gameplay spread out over 25 hours repeating the same missions over and over. There's no real reason to explore systems, especially if you don't need a technology upgrade. A little blip of story in random systems or random FTL-style encounter would make it more compelling to explore.The devs in the forums confirm that the best way to play is to put all of your points into one type of weapon. If you don't, you'll have to grind 2-3x as much to viably use multiple types of weapons. Despite all the fancy looking weapons, attachments, and mounting points in this game, you'll probably end up with a ship loaded with all of one type of weapon. You'll also quickly learn to never die so much that you run out of rez, or you'll have to grind away at a mining station for a while just to have enough money to start playing the game again.If I played again, I would play without bounty hunters. It looks like they a balancing mechanism, because the only thing they do is provide a constant drain on your resources. The diminishing returns of their arena-style missions weren't very worthwhile.It does look very good, especially when battles involve different kinds of ships, weapons, and drones flying about. The movement and turning speed plays a major role in the game, so I did like how I feels like naval warfare. Throughout the 25 hours there were fun bits unlocking new ships and figuring out what works well too, but once I figured it out it was back to the grind. It's a decent game to play while watching TV or listening to some podcasts, but it wouldn't hold my interest alone.

Posted: August 18, 2011
												This is really a good game.  And, it's only about 150MB to install.  It's a space exploration, resource gathering, space combat strategy.  I'm not much into RTS games, and this game doesn't play like one.  You have a mother ship, and then control individual ships in your fleet.  You can switch between any ship, and also set up AI for those ships you aren't currently controlling.  The galaxy is proceedurally generated when you start a new game, and you can control the number of star systems up to about 300 total.  Each star system has a level requirement before you can visit it, and you have to deal with the ships guarding the Jump Gates (bribe or destroy) before you can move freely between systems you have access to.Really, try the demo.  The tutorial is for the first system but seems to open up after about the 1st or 2nd mission you take.  This 2 person dev team deserve your money.

Posted: October 9, 2013
												I was a bit aprehensive and  couldn't decide weather to buy SPAZ or not .I left that idea for couple of weeks and  I came back to it just yesterday.Well...I have already spent over 15h of playing  SPAZ and I got to tell you :the game is well worth the money ,it is not one dimentional space game as I previously thought. It is rich and deep !You do missions and level up your ships and hangar .You collect blueprints from wreckage's and research and manufacture new components or entire ships. You can hire a specialists and train them to be more efficient as your crew.Dock to the station buy new gear there ,choose which faction you wanna be friends with and which you wanna be seen as foe .But beware there is also a group of bounty hunters that on some stage of plaing SPAZ will start  following your tracks.Travel throu spacious Universe from one solar system to another ,break through enemies gate ,develop your skills and use those ,mine Rez to get rich ,and many ,many more option in SPAZ are waiting for you.Do not hesitate ! :)

Posted: August 17, 2012
												The game is hands down one of the best indie games I have played in the past few years, easily in my top 5 indie games when you consider it's "fun factor". The graphics are very pleasing especially for a cartoon look. The sound fit's the game well as does the artwork. SPAZ has several difficulty settings ranging from "casual just play for fun and never lose" to "please just kill me now". On it's most difficult setting even the most experienced gamers will be tested. The galaxy can be created relatively small (still very large offering many hours of gameplay) to massive offering literally hundreds of hours of play time. The map is also randomly generated so replay value is high. Bounty Hunters (free DLC) adds a fourth faction to interact with adding new ways to explore or destroy star systems!All in all a highly suggested purchase that will offer something to all gamers, casual and hardcore alike.

Posted: May 18, 2012
												This game could have been called Starscape 2 (see my review on Starscape, If you have played Space Rangers its also like a much better version of that game).  Its very much similiar except quite a bit better.  First of all you get 2 NPC ships that fight along side you which you can switch between.  Second if you get stuck you can fly around to different areas and try to get better equip.  They try to keep your direction open unless you want to advance the story, then you must accomplish certain tasks. Also requires salvage to unlock ships which is a neat idea.  A bloody shame its only single player. This game is worth up to 10 dollars.  If its 5 bucks don't miss it.  On a side note the game was actually made by only 2 guys which is amazing.

Posted: October 6, 2015
												10/10 Very addictive game.  I played about 1 hour of this game 18 months ago then came back and started a new game 2 weeks ago.  It took me 80 hrs to complete a new game.  The addictive part of the game is chasing the next upgrade, blueprint or skill levelup.   I recomend game saving alot early-mid game.  The game was very challenging till, Hammerhead ship dropped toward the middle of chapter 3. The game became super easy after getting max level cannons and Mammath during chapter 4.  Mammath is OP with triple mount Partical Cannons, double mount Mass Drivers, and Battle Station.   This game reminds me of a 100x more advanced version of Asteroids, that I played hundreds of times in the mid-80s at the YMCA.  The game has a good story and great 2d graphics.  Another similarly enjoyable game to try is Reassembly.
